text: Hey <@UDU6KEBFB>, you can use any server-side language to request data to/from HubSpot. I would suggest starting with Python, as it is easy to learn. You can have a look at this post: <http://www.marinamele.com/2014/02/how-to-use-HubSpot-api-with-python.html>
yay I have a dilema... Python looks really nice and easy to learn but as a front end developer I know a bit of JS so I don't know if I continue with node.js instead of learning a new language

<@UDU6KEBFB> I think it is really about what your preference is/what you'd be comfortable with. Node.js is a great back-end programming language especially if you're already comfortable with JavaScript. As an added bonus for Node.js, you can currently use Node.js for code snippets if you work with the bots tool at all (<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/bots/running-code-snippets>). On the flip side, Python is a definitely one of the easier back-end programming languages to learn if you did want to start from scratch.

<@UDU6KEBFB> I'll second Node, but it definitely is a can of worms as there are some distinctions between server-side JS and browser JS. I'd take a look at learning the basics of NPM (node package manager, which you may already be using) along with Express, a framework that makes API development very simple imo.

I'm not that comfortable with js, I'm kind of new to coding overall and I work most of the time in CSS, so that is why I think Python is interesting because it will be more easy to learn than node.js... but if I commit to node.js it will make my skills in js more powerful and then help me with front-end projects as well. My goal is to be a decent full stack to be able to touch every kind of projects in HubSpot.

Another option you may want to consider is Ruby on Rails. It's a framework where the front-end and back-end are connected in one codebase by default, and it will also force you to learn more about actual database structure, whereas because I'm more familiar with node and express I'm more apt to work with APIs and JSON. These aren't exclusive cases, you can use APIs and databases with anything, it's just about workflow and what comes with what by default.  I'm currently learning more RoR myself and for building something fairly robust for production, it's a great system

I'm debugging an issue with our BI tool where the oauth fails for people without Super Admin privs - even people with only Admin privs.  So...I'm trying to figure out which scopes I can move into optional, and noticed that one of the scopes I have listed is "oauth"
It came from this part of the portal...

Gotcha, thanks for clarifying.  It can be used to get access token meta data via this endpoint <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/oauth2/get-access-token-information>  you can pretty safely leave that out of required scopes
Ah - thank you - I'm actually using that endpoint and metadata in our application so I'll leave it in.  Thanks!!
